questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 30.5 mg

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.
  • • Option A. Chemotherapy:
  • • Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.
  • • Option B. Brachytherapy:
  • • Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.
  • • Option D. Surgery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.
  • ➤ Staging of CA Cervix
  • ➤ TREATMENT
  • ➤ Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1 Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4
  • ➤ Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • ➤ Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4
  • ➤ Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and night sweats over the past three months. He has noticed painless swelling in his neck and armpits. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis with a predominance of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. Peripheral blood smear reveals the presence of smudge cells, and flow cytometry shows cells expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23, and negative for CD10. A lymph node biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Based on the immunophenotype and clinical features, from which cell type does CLL/SLL originate?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) originates from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells. These cells have not yet undergone somatic hypermutation or class-switch recombination typical of germinal center B cells. CLL/SLL is characterized by the accumulation of these small, mature B lymphocytes in the blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues. Flow cytometry typically shows a characteristic immunophenotype, including the expression of CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23, and lack of CD10, aligning with the cell of origin being naive or post-germinal center B cells.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Germinal center B cells Germinal center B cells give rise to other types of lymphomas, such as follicular lymphoma, but are not the origin of CLL/SLL. Germinal center cells typically undergo somatic hypermutation, which is not a feature of CLL/SLL cells.
  • • Option
  • • B. Germinal center B cells
  • • Option C. Plasma cells Plasma cells are differentiated B cells responsible for antibody production and are not involved in the pathogenesis of CLL/SLL. Plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma, originate from plasma cells, distinct from CLL/SLL.
  • • Option
  • • C. Plasma cells
  • • Option D. T cells T cells are involved in the pathogenesis of T-cell lymphomas and are unrelated to CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL specifically involves B lymphocytes, not T lymphocytes.
  • • Option
  • • D. T cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL) originates from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, characterized by a distinct immunophenotype including CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Recognizing the cellular origin is essential for understanding the disease’s pathology and guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray. Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • ➤ Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel

options.label: D
options.text: Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.correct_answer: D. Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels, preventing the initiation of a new action potential during this period.

questions.text: What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? ( INICET MAY 2023) Wide local excision Axillary node dissection Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sandfly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for managing cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its long half-life, higher bioavailability, and the convenience of not requiring routine anticoagulant monitoring.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Chop wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mucormycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. For the treatment of mucormycosis, alternative antifungal medications such as amphotericin B or posaconazole are usually used.

questions.text: A 34-year-old individual residing in a slum has experienced diarrhea, constipation, and a weight loss of 2 kg over the past two months. Physical examination reveals a dry tongue and reduced skin turgor. An endoscopic biopsy of the gut displays the following microscopic features. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms and the results from the duodenal biopsy revealing pear-shaped structures suggest a diagnosis of Giardiasis. Giardia trophozoites, which have a characteristic pear shape and two nuclei of equal size, typically adhere closely to the brush border of villous enterocytes. Although these trophozoites do not invade the tissues, they can cause significant disruption to the host's digestive functions. The presence of such trophozoites in a resident of a slum, who has experienced significant gastrointestinal symptoms, is highly indicative of Giardiasis, especially given the environment which facilitates the spread of this parasitic infection.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Entamoeba histolytica would show invasive amoebic ulcerations or flask-shaped ulcers in the colon rather than the pear-shaped trophozoites in the duodenum.
  • • Option A. Entamoeba histolytica
  • • Option B. Whipple’s disease is characterized by the presence of foamy macrophages in the intestinal lamina propria, not the findings seen in the biopsy provided.
  • • Option B. Whipple’s disease
  • • Option D. Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with gastric rather than duodenal biopsies and would show curved, rod-like bacteria on histology, typically with associated gastritis.
  • • Option D. Helicobacter pylori

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The characteristic microscopic appearance of Giardia trophozoites in duodenal biopsies is indicative of Giardiasis. These trophozoites are pear-shaped with two equally sized nuclei and attach to the intestinal brush border without invading the tissue.

questions.text: A patient presents with perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany. All the following conditions can lead to this, except: ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin D toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin D toxicity causes hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, distinguishing it from other conditions that can lead to hypocalcemia.

A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

  • ➤ Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicants is all except: (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)

options.label: D
options.text: Present medial to white rami communicantes

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Preganglionic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers. In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels. The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes. They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.
  • • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers.
  • • grey rami
  • • postganglionic
  • • In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels.
  • • white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers
  • • The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes.
  • • They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Unmyelinated : True. Grey rami communicantes primarily contain unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers. These fibers are responsible for conveying the postganglionic sympathetic impulses to the spinal nerves, which then distribute these impulses to their target tissues.
  • • Option A
  • • Unmyelinated
  • • True.
  • • Option B. Connected to spinal nerve : True. Grey rami communicantes connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to the adjacent spinal nerves. They are responsible for transmitting postganglionic sympathetic fibers to all spinal nerves (regardless of whether or not the spinal nerve level has a white ramus communicans).
  • • Option B.
  • • Connected to spinal nerve
  • • True.
  • • Option D . Present medial to white rami communicantes : True. Anatomically, when observing the sympathetic chain and its connections to the spinal nerves, the grey rami communicantes are located medially (or more centrally) relative to the white rami communicantes.
  • • Option D
  • • Present medial to white rami communicantes
  • • True.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.
  • ➤ Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening? (INICET NOV 2022) Pure tone audiometry Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 2 and 4

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up after an abnormal Pap smear showing high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL). She has a history of HPV infection confirmed by previous testing. She is asymptomatic, with no family history of cervical cancer. Colposcopy and biopsy are planned to further evaluate the abnormal findings. During counseling, the physician explains the role of HPV in cervical carcinogenesis, emphasizing the involvement of specific viral proteins in disrupting cell cycle regulation. Which protein of the human papillomavirus (HPV) is responsible for the inactivation of the Rb gene?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The E7 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of HPV-associated cancers by binding to and inactivating the Rb (Retinoblastoma) tumor suppressor gene. The Rb protein normally inhibits cell cycle progression by controlling the G1 to S phase transition, acting as a checkpoint to prevent uncontrolled cell proliferation. When E7 binds to Rb, it disrupts this regulation, leading to unchecked cellular growth, a hallmark of cancer development. This action is a central mechanism through which high-risk HPV types contribute to the development of cervical and other HPV-associated cancers.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. E5 E5 is an oncogenic protein of HPV that enhances cell proliferation by interacting with growth factor receptors and altering cellular signaling pathways. Although it plays a role in HPV's oncogenic activity, it does not directly interact with or inactivate the Rb protein.
  • • Option
  • • A. E5
  • • Option C. E1 E1 is involved in viral replication, functioning as a helicase that unwinds the viral DNA to allow replication within the host cell. It plays no role in the inactivation of tumor suppressor proteins like Rb and is not directly involved in oncogenesis.
  • • Option
  • • C. E1
  • • Option D. L2 L2 is a minor capsid protein of HPV that plays a role in viral entry, assembly, and infectivity. It does not have any direct involvement in disrupting the cell cycle or inactivating tumor suppressor genes like Rb.
  • • Option
  • • D. L2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The E7 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) binds to and inactivates the Rb tumor suppressor gene, disrupting cell cycle regulation and promoting uncontrolled cellular proliferation. This mechanism is crucial in HPV’s oncogenic process, leading to the development of cervical and other HPV-associated cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

  • ➤ not
  • ➤ maculopapular rash
  • ➤ painful, vesicular
  • ➤ dermatomal
  • ➤ rubella, dengue
  • ➤ measles
  • ➤ maculopapular rashes

  • ➤ Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
  • ➤ Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
  • ➤ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021) HbA1c >6.5 Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.
  • ➤ Falciform Ligament

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian patient presented with weakness and reduced work capacity. He had a Hb of 10gm/dl and MCV-110. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In cases of anemia with high MCV, especially in vegetarians or those with dietary restrictions, megaloblastic anemia should be considered. Vitamin B12 and folate levels should be assessed to confirm the diagnosis, and dietary intake of these vitamins should be evaluated and corrected if deficient.

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sweet’s reticulin stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sweet’s reticulin stain is specifically used to demonstrate reticular fibers in the liver, allowing for the visualization of changes in hepatocellular architecture that are not apparent with H&E staining.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of cystic fibrosis presents to the clinic with persistent abdominal pain, greasy stools, and poor weight gain despite a high-calorie diet. His past medical history is significant for recurrent respiratory infections and nasal polyps. On physical examination, he appears malnourished with a distended abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal low serum levels of pancreatic enzymes. An abdominal ultrasound shows evidence of pancreatic atrophy. A histological examination of the pancreas highlights prominent mucin accumulation and changes in the glandular structures. Based on the pathology findings, which pancreatic structure is primarily affected in patients with cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cystic fibrosis, the exocrine pancreas, specifically the acinar cells (labeled 'B' in the provided histology image), is primarily affected. The disease is characterized by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to thick mucus production that obstructs the pancreatic ducts. This obstruction results in the accumulation of mucin and subsequent atrophy of the acinar cells, which are responsible for secreting digestive enzymes. Over time, this leads to pancreatic insufficiency, resulting in malabsorption, steatorrhea, and nutritional deficiencies commonly observed in patients with cystic fibrosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Islets of Langerhans The islets of Langerhans, responsible for endocrine functions such as insulin secretion, are typically preserved in cystic fibrosis, especially in early disease. They are not the primary structures affected by the mucin accumulation and pancreatic ductal obstruction seen in this condition.
  • • Option
  • • A. Islets of Langerhans
  • • Option C. Main Pancreatic Duct While the main pancreatic duct can be obstructed by thick mucus, leading to overall pancreatic dysfunction, the primary damage in cystic fibrosis occurs at the level of the acinar cells. The duct itself is not the main site of tissue atrophy but contributes indirectly to the damage.
  • • Option
  • • C. Main Pancreatic Duct
  • • Option D. Connective Tissue Septa The connective tissue septa provide structural support to the pancreas but are not directly affected by the pathological processes in cystic fibrosis. The septa may become more prominent as acinar atrophy progresses, but they are not primarily involved in the disease’s pathogenesis.
  • • Option
  • • D. Connective Tissue Septa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cystic fibrosis, the exocrine pancreas, particularly the acinar cells, is primarily affected due to mucus accumulation and obstruction of the ducts, leading to acinar atrophy and pancreatic insufficiency. Understanding this pathology is crucial for recognizing the nutritional and digestive complications associated with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Leaves of broad ligament:
  • • Leaves of broad ligament:
  • • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men. In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy. As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include: Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include: Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni
  • • Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
  • • Koblet’s tubules
  • • Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
  • • Epoophoron
  • • Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
  • • Para-oophoron
  • • Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Gartner’s duct
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.
  • • Option A. Pouch of Douglas:
  • • Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.
  • • Option C. Uterovesical pouch:
  • • Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.
  • • Option D. Iliac fossa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: The liver biopsy histopathology of a patient diagnosed with hemochromatosis is shown below. Which stain has been used to obtain this image? (AIIMS NOV 2016 )
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The biopsy image provided demonstrates the presence of blue-black staining, characteristic of Prussian blue stain, which specifically targets iron deposits. In the context of hemochromatosis, a condition marked by excessive iron accumulation in the liver and other organs, the Prussian blue stain is utilized to detect the hemosiderin, an iron-storage complex. The iron in hemosiderin reacts with potassium ferrocyanide in the Prussian blue staining process, highlighting the affected areas in a blue-black color, confirming iron overload.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Alcian blue is primarily used for staining acidic mucopolysaccharides and glycosaminoglycans in tissues, not iron.
  • • Option A. Alcian blue
  • • Option C. Crystal violet is used for staining cell nuclei and not for iron.
  • • Option C. Crystal violet
  • • Option D. Von Kossa stain is used to detect calcium deposits, not iron.
  • • Option D. Von Kossa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Prussian blue stain is used to detect iron deposits in tissues, turning them blue-black, and is particularly significant in diagnosing conditions like hemochromatosis where iron overload is a key feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) INSM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia

options.label: B
options.text: Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs

options.label: D
options.text: It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.correct_answer: D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.
  • • In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity
  • • Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.
  • • Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited
  • • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs. It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.
  • • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia : Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.
  • • Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
  • • Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs : Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.
  • • Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
  • • Option C. Rigidity is pronounced : This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.
  • • Option C. Rigidity is pronounced

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

questions.text: Cells lining the isthmus of the gastric pits? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match regarding FDA approved antidotes of anticoagulants? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Andexanet alfa is the approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors like Edoxaban and Rivaroxaban, while Idarucizumab is the antidote for Dabigatran. Although Ciraparantag has shown promise as a broad-spectrum antidote, it is not FDA-approved for use with fondaparinux or other anticoagulants.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his developmental delays and behavior. A family history reveals that other male relatives have had similar developmental and behavioral issues. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Fragile X syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fragile X syndrome is characterized by macro-orchidism (enlarged testicles), not micro-orchidism, especially noticeable in post-pubertal males. The syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, leading to a deficiency in FMRP, a protein critical for neural development. Common physical features include a long face, large ears, prominent forehead, and behavioral problems such as intellectual disability and autism spectrum traits. The hallmark finding of macro-orchidism helps differentiate Fragile X syndrome from other genetic disorders.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Macro-orchidism Macro-orchidism, or enlarged testicles, is a classic feature of Fragile X syndrome and often becomes more apparent during puberty. It is one of the key distinguishing characteristics seen in males with this condition.
  • • Option
  • • A. Macro-orchidism
  • • Option B. Large ears Large, often everted ears are a common feature of Fragile X syndrome and contribute to the distinct facial appearance. This feature, along with other craniofacial abnormalities, helps clinicians suspect the diagnosis in affected individuals.
  • • Option
  • • B. Large ears
  • • Option D. Intellectual disability Intellectual disability is a core feature of Fragile X syndrome, typically ranging from mild to severe. It is often accompanied by learning difficulties, speech delays, and behavioral issues such as anxiety and hyperactivity.
  • • Option
  • • D. Intellectual disability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene, leading to macro-orchidism, intellectual disability, distinct craniofacial features, and behavioral challenges. It is important to recognize that macro-orchidism, not micro-orchidism, is characteristic of this disorder, helping to differentiate it from other genetic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Psoas abscess are true? ( INICET MAY 2022 )

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Faggot cell

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A faggot cell, characterized by multiple Auer rods clustered together in a single cell, is highly indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). While Auer rods are a feature of various forms of AML, the presence of faggot cells is particularly associated with APL.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. Imaging studies reveal a pseudoaneurysm involving an artery. What is the most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femoral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues. The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access. Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries. Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis). The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation. The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography. Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion. MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.
  • ➤ A pseudoaneurysm is a pulsatile hematoma that forms when there is a breach in the arterial wall, resulting in the extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues.
  • ➤ The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation is the femoral artery, due to its superficial location and frequent use for arterial access.
  • ➤ Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in other arteries, such as the brachial, radial, ulnar, and carotid arteries.
  • ➤ Common causes of pseudoaneurysm formation include trauma, iatrogenic injury during medical procedures (e.g., arterial catheterization), and underlying arterial disease (e.g., atherosclerosis).
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of a pseudoaneurysm may include a pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and signs of bleeding or hematoma formation.
  • ➤ The diagnosis of a pseudoaneurysm is confirmed by imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography.
  • ➤ Treatment options for a pseudoaneurysm may include observation, compression, percutaneous thrombin injection, or surgical repair depending on the size, location, and underlying cause of the lesion.
  • ➤ MC site of true peripheral aneurysm is however, the popliteal artery.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Apoptosis

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded). After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).
  • ➤ Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).
  • ➤ Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal distension and intermittent fever. Peripheral smear findings are normal. A tumor is resected and the histopathology image of the resected lymph node is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Castleman disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Castleman disease is a lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by follicular hyperplasia and is associated with HHV-8 in some cases. The treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors due to the elevated IL-6 levels.
  • ➤ Castleman disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a history of chronic abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. She has undergone multiple evaluations without a definitive diagnosis. A recent endoscopic biopsy of the colon was performed to further investigate her symptoms. The pathology report noted an abundance of mucin within the tissue, and the pathologist performed several special stains to differentiate the types of mucins present. The pathologist notes the presence of acid mucins in the biopsy sample and mentions the specific stain used to identify them. Which stain is used to identify acid mucin?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alcian blue is a histochemical stain used specifically to identify acid mucins, which include acid-simple non-sulfated mucins, acid-complex sulfated mucins, and acid-complex connective tissue mucins. Alcian blue stains these acidic mucins blue, allowing for their clear visualization under the microscope. However, it does not stain neutral mucins, making it highly specific for detecting acidic mucin types in tissues. This staining is particularly useful in diagnosing mucinous lesions in the gastrointestinal tract and other organs where acid mucins are prevalent.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Mucicarmine Mucicarmine is a specific stain for epithelial mucins, especially those found in adenocarcinomas. It is not used to identify acid mucins specifically, but rather highlights epithelial mucins, making it more useful in the identification of glandular tissues and certain tumors.
  • • Option
  • • B. Mucicarmine
  • • Option C. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) PAS stains both glycogen and mucins, including neutral and some acid mucins. It is a broad-spectrum stain that does not specifically distinguish acid mucins alone and can also highlight other carbohydrate-rich substances within tissues.
  • • Option
  • • C. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)
  • • Option D. Colloidal iron Colloidal iron stains acid mucins, including acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-complex sulfated mucins, but it does not stain connective tissue mucins. It is an alternative stain for acid mucins, but its specificity and utility differ from that of Alcian blue.
  • • Option
  • • D. Colloidal iron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcian blue is a histochemical stain that specifically identifies acid mucins, including both non-sulfated and sulfated types. It is widely used in pathology to highlight acidic mucin types in tissues, aiding in the diagnosis of mucin-producing lesions, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2

options.label: B
options.text: Cell cycle will stop at G1

options.label: C
options.text: There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed

options.label: D
options.text: The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.correct_answer: B. Cell cycle will stop at G1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypophosphorylated state of the Rb protein prevents the cell cycle from progressing past the G1 phase by binding to and inactivating E2F, thereby acting as a crucial checkpoint in preventing uncontrolled cell proliferation.

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

questions.text: Cancer that least commonly spreads by lymphatic route is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Basal Cell Carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a locally invasive tumor that rarely spreads via the lymphatic or hematogenous routes, distinguishing it from other more aggressive skin cancers.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma
  • ➤ locally invasive tumor
  • ➤ rarely spreads

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis

options.label: B
options.text: It is produced in response to bacterial infection.

options.label: D
options.text: It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? ( INICET MAY 2023)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.
